texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: What is Sales Training?
texts.text: What is Sales Training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: It sounds self-explanatory. Sales training is the act of training your sales team. The definition gets complex when you consider how many types of sales there are. A sales rep trained in telemarketing might not do well in field sales.
texts.text: It sounds self-explanatory. Sales training is the act of training your sales team. The definition gets complex when you consider how many types of sales there are. A sales rep trained in telemarketing might not do well in field sales.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Not to mention the techniques, product knowledge, and mindset that create the core of a successful salesperson.
texts.text: Not to mention the techniques, product knowledge, and mindset that create the core of a successful salesperson.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Sales training that works is an investment that reinvigorates your team and revenue. It will be suited toward your industry and personalized for your business.
texts.text: Sales training that works is an investment that reinvigorates your team and revenue. It will be suited toward your industry and personalized for your business.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The training itself can be a motivational seminar or an in-depth workshop. Sales reps can be trained one-on-one or in a group. Your reps can even use sales exercises to train each other for practically nothing.
texts.text: The training itself can be a motivational seminar or an in-depth workshop. Sales reps can be trained one-on-one or in a group. Your reps can even use sales exercises to train each other for practically nothing.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Why Should You Consider Sales Training?
texts.text: Why Should You Consider Sales Training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: A lot of sales reps start their career without any training at all. The sinkor-swim nature of sales creates the idea that good performance is intuitive. You either swim (and sell) or sink (and fail).
texts.text: A lot of sales reps start their career without any training at all. The sinkor-swim nature of sales creates the idea that good performance is intuitive. You either swim (and sell) or sink (and fail).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: It's true, sales is a difficult career.
texts.text: It's true, sales is a difficult career.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: That being said, you don't need natural talent to succeed. Like all difficult things, salesmanship can be learned - even mastered - with the right training.
texts.text: That being said, you don't need natural talent to succeed. Like all difficult things, salesmanship can be learned - even mastered - with the right training.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Considering the fact that is costs an average of $114,957 to replace a sales rep, throwing your sales team a life preserver can benefit your entire organization.
texts.text: Considering the fact that is costs an average of $114,957 to replace a sales rep, throwing your sales team a life preserver can benefit your entire organization.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Investing in sales training sends a positive message to your sales team. It shows interest in their performance, results, and careers. It also happens to be the perfect recipe to bring out the top-performers on your team.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: How to Cut Your Sales Team's Training Time By Half
texts.text: How to Cut Your Sales Team's Training Time By Half

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Sales training is only half the battle. Your reps need to be efficient and productive as quickly as possible. Maintaining your sales team's focus throughout the sales cycle can be a balancing act in itself.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: So much time and money is invested into hiring and onboarding sales reps that any decrease in the amount of time spent selling will eat into your company's profit.
texts.text: So much time and money is invested into hiring and onboarding sales reps that any decrease in the amount of time spent selling will eat into your company's profit.

texts.text: L'Oreal asked a similar question when they examined their onboarding process. Their solution was to find a way to reduce training time while maintaining scale and sales efficiency.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The L'Oreal sales team adopted Badger Maps as their solution, reducing their training time for new reps by 50%.
texts.text: The L'Oreal sales team adopted Badger Maps as their solution, reducing their training time for new reps by 50%.

texts.label: text

texts.text: L'Oreal reps were taking an average of 1 year to reach full productivity. Badger reduced total training time to 6 months. Badger acts as L'Oreal's training program by educating new reps on territory, customers, and best practices.

texts.label: text

texts.orig: Choosing the sales training program that's right for your company depends entirely on your sales process. Your sales process is the customer-facing side of your business. Everything leading up to (and resulting in) a sale is considered part of the process.

texts.label: text

texts.orig: How to create case-based Product Sales Training:
texts.text: How to create case-based Product Sales Training:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1. Get your most experienced reps, managers, and training developers to create the training material using as much product knowledge as possible.
texts.text: Get your most experienced reps, managers, and training developers to create the training material using as much product knowledge as possible.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2. Use their knowledge to define the most commonly encountered sales situations. Categorize them by types that are relevant to your business (high value sale, cold call, consultative appointment, transactional sale, etc)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3.Work through these sales situations to discover the thought process behind each. Really digging into each type of sales situation will let you know what kind of product knowledge is required for each situation.
texts.text: 3.Work through these sales situations to discover the thought process behind each. Really digging into each type of sales situation will let you know what kind of product knowledge is required for each situation.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4. Any non-essential product information can be compiled into a reference guide for less-common situations.
texts.text: Any non-essential product information can be compiled into a reference guide for less-common situations.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 5. Incorporate the sales methodology and skills your top reps use in each scenario.
texts.text: Incorporate the sales methodology and skills your top reps use in each scenario.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 6. Now that your sales scenarios involve relevant product knowledge you'll always have engaging product sales training material.
texts.text: Now that your sales scenarios involve relevant product knowledge you'll always have engaging product sales training material.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Conceptual Selling
texts.text: Conceptual Selling

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Conceptual selling was developed by Miller Heiman of MHI Global. It focuses on the idea that the consumer does not buy a product, they buy the results of that product.
texts.text: Conceptual selling was developed by Miller Heiman of MHI Global. It focuses on the idea that the consumer does not buy a product, they buy the results of that product.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This is similar to focusing on the benefits of your product over the features it contains. People are looking for a solution, understanding how you provide that to them makes your product more appealing.
texts.text: This is similar to focusing on the benefits of your product over the features it contains. People are looking for a solution, understanding how you provide that to them makes your product more appealing.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Conceptual selling uncovers the decision-making process of the customer instead of leading with a pitch. Being customer-focused is an idea that occurs often in sales training, and for good reason. Buyers have a lot of options, understanding their needs and wants is essential to earning their loyalty. Conceptual selling breaks the sale down into 3 stages:
texts.text: Conceptual selling uncovers the decision-making process of the customer instead of leading with a pitch. Conceptual selling breaks the sale down into 3 stages:

texts.text: Ask questions to determine the making decision-making process of your customer.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1.  Who are they?
texts.text: Who are they?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2.  What are the problems they're facing?
texts.text: What are the problems they're facing?

texts.label: list_item

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Giving information involves tailoring your solution to the needs of your prospect. This stage is about connecting their problem to your solution.
texts.text: Giving information involves tailoring your solution to the needs of your prospect. This stage is about connecting their problem to your solution.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● How your solution fits their concept
texts.text: How your solution fits their concept

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● How your solution is a better fit than competitive solutions
texts.text: How your solution is a better fit than competitive solutions

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● The unique strength of your offer, custom-fit to your prospect's concept
texts.text: The unique strength of your offer, custom-fit to your prospect's concept

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The information you give should be only what your customer needs. Don't waste time by focusing on irrelevant details.
texts.text: The information you give should be only what your customer needs. Don't waste time by focusing on irrelevant details.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Getting commitment

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Getting commitment from your prospect is extremely important. You want them to commit to another interaction at the very least, and an agreement to purchase as the relationship progresses.
texts.text: Getting commitment from your prospect is extremely important. You want them to commit to another interaction at the very least, and an agreement to purchase as the relationship progresses.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● Get a commitment of further engagement after every interaction

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● Get greater commitments as the sales relationship progresses
texts.text: Get greater commitments as the sales relationship progresses

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● If your customer refuses a commitment they are doubting your solution. Discover the reason behind their hesitation and provide more information on how your solution solves their specific problem
texts.text: If your customer refuses a commitment they are doubting your solution. Discover the reason behind their hesitation and provide more information on how your solution solves their specific problem

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Your entire interaction with your customer should be based around their concept of the solution they need. That means listening is more important than speaking. If you can understand their problem you'll be the best fit for their solution.
texts.text: Your entire interaction with your customer should be based around their concept of the solution they need. That means listening is more important than speaking. If you can understand their problem you'll be the best fit for their solution.

texts.label: text

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Chapter 11 Sales Skill Training
texts.text: Chapter 11 Sales Skill Training

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Sales skill training increases the efficiency of sales skills and techniques. It covers the "how" of sales, the nitty-gritty and personal aspects of closing deals. Sales skill training is typically in-person and physical.
texts.text: Sales skill training increases the efficiency of sales skills and techniques. It covers the "how" of sales, the nitty-gritty and personal aspects of closing deals. Sales skill training is typically in-person and physical.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Sales skill training depends on regular practice. The training program will generally provide a regimen for each rep to follow designed to improve selling skills. Live coaching, practice calls, and peer-review of technique are essential aspect of sales skill training.
texts.text: Sales skill training depends on regular practice. The training program will generally provide a regimen for each rep to follow designed to improve selling skills. Live coaching, practice calls, and peer-review of technique are essential aspect of sales skill training.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The sales skills your team requires depends on your sales process. An inside sales team should focus on tonality more than body language, for example.
texts.text: The sales skills your team requires depends on your sales process. An inside sales team should focus on tonality more than body language, for example.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: That being said, there are fundamental sales skills that every salesperson should know. These skills are basic aspects of communication and persuasion and should be covered by any sales skill training program you invest in.
texts.text: That being said, there are fundamental sales skills that every salesperson should know. These skills are basic aspects of communication and persuasion and should be covered by any sales skill training program you invest in.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Sales Skill Training Fundamentals
texts.text: Sales Skill Training Fundamentals

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The most fundamental sales skills are also useful in everyday life. Suprise, communication and persuasion are daily activities. This section is written directly to your sales rep to help convey all of the different skills that go into sales.
texts.text: The most fundamental sales skills are also useful in everyday life. Suprise, communication and persuasion are daily activities. This section is written directly to your sales rep to help convey all of the different skills that go into sales.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Conversation
texts.text: Conversation

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Conversation creates sales. Communication has been the basis of every sale since the dawn of time. How well the value of your solution is communicated decides if it's sold or not. That's not changing anytime soon.
texts.text: Conversation creates sales. Communication has been the basis of every sale since the dawn of time. How well the value of your solution is communicated decides if it's sold or not. That's not changing anytime soon.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Conversational skill is a priority in any sales skill training program. Time magazine studied 'The Art of Conversation' and found 5 fundamental rules:
texts.text: Conversational skill is a priority in any sales skill training program. Time magazine studied 'The Art of Conversation' and found 5 fundamental rules:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1.  Put others at ease
texts.text: Put others at ease

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2.  Put yourself at ease
texts.text: Put yourself at ease

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3.  Weave in all parties
texts.text: Weave in all parties

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4.  Establish shared interests
texts.text: Establish shared interests

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 5.  Actively pursue your own
texts.text: Actively pursue your own

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In sales, the conversation is between you and your (potential) customer, which creates a unique dynamic. Both of you are trying to get something from the conversation. You want a sale and your customer wants a solution, both of you want the best deal possible.
texts.text: In sales, the conversation is between you and your (potential) customer, which creates a unique dynamic. Both of you are trying to get something from the conversation. You want a sale and your customer wants a solution, both of you want the best deal possible.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: With that in mind, let's look at the rules of conversation from a sales perspective:
texts.text: With that in mind, let's look at the rules of conversation from a sales perspective:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● Put yourself at ease - Be calm, cool, and collected. If you seem nervous you'll make your customer nervous. Speak slowly and with intent to show
texts.text: Put yourself at ease - Be calm, cool, and collected. If you seem nervous you'll make your customer nervous. Speak slowly and with intent to show

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: confidence in the situation and your solution. The success of the conversation (and ultimately, the sale) is completely based on trust. By appearing at ease in the conversation you're making your customer feel equally confident.
texts.text: confidence in the situation and your solution. The success of the conversation (and ultimately, the sale) is completely based on trust. By appearing at ease in the conversation you're making your customer feel equally confident.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● Put others at ease - Make your buyer feel comfortable. Don't control the conversation. Listen and make sure they understand they're being heard. Their time is as valuable as yours, respecting their side of the conversation ensures they'll respect yours.
texts.text: Put others at ease - Make your buyer feel comfortable. Don't control the conversation. Listen and make sure they understand they're being heard. Their time is as valuable as yours, respecting their side of the conversation ensures they'll respect yours.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● Weave in all parties - Don't leave anyone out of the conversation. You can never be completely sure about who has influence in a group. Leaving a key decision maker out of the conversation, or ignoring their concerns, is a surefire way to lose the sale.
texts.text: Weave in all parties - Don't leave anyone out of the conversation. You can never be completely sure about who has influence in a group. Leaving a key decision maker out of the conversation, or ignoring their concerns, is a surefire way to lose the sale.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● Establish shared interests - Connect the conversation to the life of your buyer. They are looking for a solution to their specific problem. You can make your offering much more relevant by connecting it to their life. This also shows that you're listening, and that you care about more than just the sale.
texts.text: Establish shared interests - Connect the conversation to the life of your buyer. They are looking for a solution to their specific problem. You can make your offering much more relevant by connecting it to their life. This also shows that you're listening, and that you care about more than just the sale.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ● Actively pursue your own - Don't be afraid to actually sell. You aren't doing anyone any favors by ignoring the purpose of the conversation. Balancing the sale with genuine interest in your customer will help you stand out as an excellent salesperson.
texts.text: Actively pursue your own - Don't be afraid to actually sell. You aren't doing anyone any favors by ignoring the purpose of the conversation. Balancing the sale with genuine interest in your customer will help you stand out as an excellent salesperson.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: These rules help ensure that the sales conversation develops in a mutually beneficial way for your rep and your buyer. Make your sales team memorize them and watch the revenue flow. The following skills are based in conversational ability. Improving them should be daily practice for your sales team.
texts.text: These rules help ensure that the sales conversation develops in a mutually beneficial way for your rep and your buyer. Make your sales team memorize them and watch the revenue flow. The following skills are based in conversational ability. Improving them should be daily practice for your sales team.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Presentation
texts.text: Presentation

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Presentation skills help you get your message across. You never know when you'll need to present your product to one person or when a group will need a demonstration.
texts.text: Presentation skills help you get your message across. You never know when you'll need to present your product to one person or when a group will need a demonstration.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Present confidently with appropriate body language. Speak slowly to help your audience absorb the information.
texts.text: Present confidently with appropriate body language. Speak slowly to help your audience absorb the information.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Your presentation (along with your sales pitch) should actively guide your prospect into being a customer, not ignore them so that you can get your message across.
texts.text: Your presentation (along with your sales pitch) should actively guide your prospect into being a customer, not ignore them so that you can get your message across.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Active Listening
texts.text: Active Listening

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Listening to your prospect is the most effective way of getting the sale. Active listening involves hearing what your customer is saying while also understanding what they mean.
texts.text: Listening to your prospect is the most effective way of getting the sale. Active listening involves hearing what your customer is saying while also understanding what they mean.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The questions you ask your prospect should be based on the details they give you. Your job, as a sales rep, is to weave together your prospect's problems and the solution you're selling.
texts.text: The questions you ask your prospect should be based on the details they give you. Your job, as a sales rep, is to weave together your prospect's problems and the solution you're selling.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Storytelling
texts.text: Storytelling

texts.label: text
texts.orig: What better way to weave ideas together than storytelling? Salespeople must be good storytellers. You need to communicate the value of your solution to your customer's life, telling a story to your prospect about how your product helped someone just like them is the best way to do that.
texts.text: What better way to weave ideas together than storytelling? Salespeople must be good storytellers. You need to communicate the value of your solution to your customer's life, telling a story to your prospect about how your product helped someone just like them is the best way to do that.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Practice speaking with a narrative structure. Provide a setting, characters, and conflict with a satisfying resolution (involving your product!) and you'll capture your prospects attention and close the sale.
texts.text: Practice speaking with a narrative structure. Provide a setting, characters, and conflict with a satisfying resolution (involving your product!) and you'll capture your prospects attention and close the sale.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Building Rapport
texts.text: Building Rapport

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Rapport creates relationships. Relationships make sales. Your prospect needs to like you, or at least tolerate you, before they'll buy from you.
texts.text: Rapport creates relationships. Relationships make sales. Your prospect needs to like you, or at least tolerate you, before they'll buy from you.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Establishing rapport involves connecting with your prospect. Trade opinions, share stories, and bond over common ground. Don't rush into the sale while ignoring that your prospect is a person, just like you.
texts.text: Establishing rapport involves connecting with your prospect. Trade opinions, share stories, and bond over common ground. Don't rush into the sale while ignoring that your prospect is a person, just like you.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Assertiveness
texts.text: Assertiveness

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Being assertive doesn't mean being rude. You can be assertive in a friendly, and even passive, manner.
texts.text: Being assertive doesn't mean being rude. You can be assertive in a friendly, and even passive, manner.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Direct the conversation towards the goal of the meeting. Both you and your prospect know why you're meeting, there's no shame in bringing the goal of the meeting into focus at the appropriate time.
texts.text: Direct the conversation towards the goal of the meeting. Both you and your prospect know why you're meeting, there's no shame in bringing the goal of the meeting into focus at the appropriate time.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Conquering Objections
texts.text: Conquering Objections

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Overcoming objections is one of the most uncomfortable aspects of sales. You have to disagree with someone, a scary idea for salespeople and non-reps alike.
texts.text: Overcoming objections is one of the most uncomfortable aspects of sales. You have to disagree with someone, a scary idea for salespeople and non-reps alike.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: It helps to understand that you're not disagreeing with the person , only their idea . If you're sure that your solution will make their life better than you're doing them a favor by bringing them to your point of view. People are naturally unsure, it's your job to give them all of the facts they need to make a decision.
texts.text: It helps to understand that you're not disagreeing with the person , only their idea . If you're sure that your solution will make their life better than you're doing them a favor by bringing them to your point of view. People are naturally unsure, it's your job to give them all of the facts they need to make a decision.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The basic process of overcoming objections is to:
texts.text: The basic process of overcoming objections is to:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Understand 'What's preventing you from making a decision today?'
texts.text: Understand 'What's preventing you from making a decision today?'

texts.label: text
texts.orig: E mpathize 'I understand why that might be an issue'
texts.text: E mpathize 'I understand why that might be an issue'

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Overcome 'Will this fix ____? If not, what will?'
texts.text: Overcome 'Will this fix ____? If not, what will?'

texts.label: text
texts.orig: A good sales skill training program teaches your team to overcome common objections in your industry. Specificity is key when addressing customer concerns.
texts.text: A good sales skill training program teaches your team to overcome common objections in your industry. Specificity is key when addressing customer concerns.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Closing
texts.text: Closing

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Closing a deal is getting a decision from your prospect, hopefully turning them into a customer.
texts.text: Closing a deal is getting a decision from your prospect, hopefully turning them into a customer.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: There are a variety of ways to improve close rate, but there's one fundamental thing you'll need to do:
texts.text: There are a variety of ways to improve close rate, but there's one fundamental thing you'll need to do:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Ask with confidence - Consider asking for the sale mandatory. If you've used your sales skills effectively your prospect will be ready to buy, if not, they would have left already.
texts.text: Ask with confidence - Consider asking for the sale mandatory. If you've used your sales skills effectively your prospect will be ready to buy, if not, they would have left already.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Still, a decision is a scary thing for prospects. By asking for the sale (with confidence) you're taking the pressure off of your customer and placing it on yourself. This is usually appreciated and prevents any delay on the part of your prospect.
texts.text: Still, a decision is a scary thing for prospects. By asking for the sale (with confidence) you're taking the pressure off of your customer and placing it on yourself. This is usually appreciated and prevents any delay on the part of your prospect.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Cross-Selling & Up-Selling
texts.text: Cross-Selling & Up-Selling

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Cross-selling and up-selling are advanced skills. They involve selling to your customer even more , either a related product or a more expensive version of what they're buying.
texts.text: Cross-selling and up-selling are advanced skills. They involve selling to your customer even more , either a related product or a more expensive version of what they're buying.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Getting more from each sale is a hallmark characteristic of a good salesperson.
texts.text: Getting more from each sale is a hallmark characteristic of a good salesperson.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Cross-selling involves selling related products that your customer can use in addition to the one they've bought. A good way to introduce a cross-sale is to connect the related product with another need of your customer.
texts.text: Cross-selling involves selling related products that your customer can use in addition to the one they've bought. A good way to introduce a cross-sale is to connect the related product with another need of your customer.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Up-selling involves pitching a more expensive version of your product after your prospect has decided to buy the regular version.
texts.text: Up-selling involves pitching a more expensive version of your product after your prospect has decided to buy the regular version.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: A good way to think about up-selling is that you're giving your customer more options. As long as you know they'll value the upgraded version more than the regular you're doing them a favor by mentioning it.
texts.text: A good way to think about up-selling is that you're giving your customer more options. As long as you know they'll value the upgraded version more than the regular you're doing them a favor by mentioning it.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Both cross-selling and up-selling require a deep understanding of your customer's business. Before you ask them for a greater investment of time and money, you need to know how that investment will benefit them.
texts.text: Both cross-selling and up-selling require a deep understanding of your customer's business. Before you ask them for a greater investment of time and money, you need to know how that investment will benefit them.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Cross-selling and up-selling are both best for when a relationship has already been established. That is, when you've already closed a sale with this customer.
texts.text: Cross-selling and up-selling are both best for when a relationship has already been established. That is, when you've already closed a sale with this customer.

texts.orig: Jim Cathcart
texts.text: Jim Cathcart

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Bio: Jim Cathcart, CSP, CPAE is the original author of Relationship Selling™ plus 16 other books. He is one of the most award winning professional speakers on Earth and has delivered over 3,000 seminars and speeches worldwide. In 2012 he was inducted into the Sales & Marketing Hall of Fame by Top Sales World Magazine. His books and concepts are being taught in universities and corporations around the world. He is also a professional guitarist and songwriter plus a mountain trail runner based in California. http://cathcart.com/

He is one of the most award winning professional speakers on Earth and has delivered over 3,000 seminars and speeches worldwide. In 2012 he was inducted into the Sales & Marketing Hall of Fame by Top Sales World Magazine. His books and concepts are being taught in universities and corporations around the world. texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 1. How long have you been in sales? What industry?
texts.text: 1. How long have you been in sales? What industry?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: I've been both a sales person and a sales trainer in many capacities over the years. I started out as a kid selling my old toys and comic books from a table in my front yard, then selling various products and services door-todoor. As a young adult I sold cars, mutual funds, life insurance and business services. Once I got into the field of Training & Development I sold Earl Nightingale's training materials and then my own. I started in this field in 1974 and went full time on my own in 1977. My clients have been in hundreds of industries and professions. I started in Financial Services: Banking, Life Insurance and Investment Products.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 2. What do you incorporate in your sales training? Can you describe the process?
texts.text: 2. What do you incorporate in your sales training? Can you describe the process?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: I'm the original author and champion of the concept known as 'Relationship Selling™'. I wrote the first book by that title and worked through the resistance in the market when I first introduced the phrase. People used to say, 'Jim you have to choose; it's either a relationship or a sale!'
texts.text: I'm the original author and champion of the concept known as 'Relationship Selling™'. I wrote the first book by that title and worked through the resistance in the market when I first introduced the phrase. People used to say, 'Jim you have to choose; it's either a relationship or a sale!'

texts.label: text
texts.orig: My belief is that Relationships are either Assets or Liabilities depending on how you manage them. In Relationship Selling™ we approach connections as Assets and track and manage them accordingly.
texts.text: My belief is that Relationships are either Assets or Liabilities depending on how you manage them. In Relationship Selling™ we approach connections as Assets and track and manage them accordingly.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In Sales Training topics must include: Sales Philosophy (What is selling and why does it matter?), Sales Process, Sales Techniques, SelfManagement and Self-Motivation, Interpersonal Communication, Understanding Buyer Differences: Values, Thinking Style, Personality Type, Velocity differences, and cultivating Trust.
texts.text: In Sales Training topics must include: Sales Philosophy (What is selling and why does it matter?), Sales Process, Sales Techniques, SelfManagement and Self-Motivation, Interpersonal Communication, Understanding Buyer Differences: Values, Thinking Style, Personality Type, Velocity differences, and cultivating Trust.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 3. How does technology shape your sales process? What tools do you use/recommend to use?
texts.text: 3. How does technology shape your sales process? What tools do you use/recommend to use?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: I don't specify a particular approach to technology in sales because companies and markets vary as to which is the best tool. Clearly we must optimize our selling with the media, instruments and strategies that generate the most trust and credibility as well as the best outcomes. Life is much easier with the right technology.
texts.text: I don't specify a particular approach to technology in sales because companies and markets vary as to which is the best tool. Clearly we must optimize our selling with the media, instruments and strategies that generate the most trust and credibility as well as the best outcomes. Life is much easier with the right technology.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 4. What is the key component of your sales training?
texts.text: 4. What is the key component of your sales training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Mindset. It shows up in each phase of the sale. I teach Relationship Selling™ with a structure that I call 'The Eight Competencies' structured around the skill sets needed for each phase of selling: Preparation, Targeting the right buyers, Connecting with them to gain trust, Assessing their needs and wants, Solving their problem, Confirming their commitment to buy, Assuring satisfaction and Managing Sales and Self.
texts.text: Mindset. It shows up in each phase of the sale. I teach Relationship Selling™ with a structure that I call 'The Eight Competencies' structured around the skill sets needed for each phase of selling: Preparation, Targeting the right buyers, Connecting with them to gain trust, Assessing their needs and wants, Solving their problem, Confirming their commitment to buy, Assuring satisfaction and Managing Sales and Self.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: I continually reinforce the Mindset that: Selling is an act of friendship, not a process of simple persuasion. The purpose of Selling is: To Make Life Better For The Buyer.
texts.text: I continually reinforce the Mindset that: Selling is an act of friendship, not a process of simple persuasion. The purpose of Selling is: To Make Life Better For The Buyer.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5. What are the best results you've seen from your sales training process?
texts.text: 5. What are the best results you've seen from your sales training process?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: I spent 6 years working with a life insurance agency and they went from nearly out of business to winning the President's Trophy twice in a 5 year period with a fifteen fold increase in production ($17 million to $231 million) and a minimal increase in their sales force (19 agents).
texts.text: I spent 6 years working with a life insurance agency and they went from nearly out of business to winning the President's Trophy twice in a 5 year period with a fifteen fold increase in production ($17 million to $231 million) and a minimal increase in their sales force (19 agents).

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6. What are the most important skills you can have as a sales trainer?
texts.text: 6. What are the most important skills you can have as a sales trainer?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Self Awareness, Self Motivation and Self Management. If you can understand and control yourself effectively then you will also understand others better and be able to reach more of them. Self Motivation means getting yourself to do what needs to be done even when you don't feel like it.
texts.text: Self Awareness, Self Motivation and Self Management. If you can understand and control yourself effectively then you will also understand others better and be able to reach more of them. Self Motivation means getting yourself to do what needs to be done even when you don't feel like it.

texts.text: 8. What was your most important learning experience?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When Doug Macdonald told me to stop selling and start helping. He said,
texts.text: When Doug Macdonald told me to stop selling and start helping. He said,

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 'Jim you know all the right words and you can manipulate people into saying Yes but that's not your job. Your job as a sales person is to help them and earn a profit by doing so. When you cannot help someone then you shouldn't be selling to them. There are plenty of other prospects. Make what you do count.

texts.text: 1 0. What advice would you give a new sales trainer?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Be sure you focus on Outcomes! Don't get stuck in processes unless those processes lead to desirable outcomes. It is the helping that matters, the selling is just a way to get there. All sales people should get better each month for their entire career. The way you know it's working is that they need you less and less in order to produce sales increases.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 7. Why should companies invest in sales training?
texts.text: 7. Why should companies invest in sales training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Buyer expectations are higher than ever. What worked back in the day, is outdated now. Buyers do not want the feature dump and your demo isn't that important (at least in the beginning). The Harvard Business Review reported that more than 70% of executive buyers said that the ability for a salesperson to demonstrate that they can solve business problems is key to their decision making process. It is a new world and it is costly for a business to let their salespeople figure it out as they go. They need to be training in how to be good consultative sellers and that training should happen on an ongoing and consistent basis. The problem is that often companies think of training as an event and not a process, which is a big mistake.
texts.text: Buyer expectations are higher than ever. What worked back in the day, is outdated now. Buyers do not want the feature dump and your demo isn't that important (at least in the beginning). They need to be training in how to be good consultative sellers and that training should happen on an ongoing and consistent basis. The problem is that often companies think of training as an event and not a process, which is a big mistake.

texts.orig: That learning never ends. Every day I make it my business to learn something new. That keeps you relevant. No matter how much experience you have, you never can know it all. Salespeople who think they already know it all are definitely setting themselves up for failure. That is more true today than ever. With new technologies popping up daily, salespeople have to keep up. And, because buyers expect more than your dog and pony show, you need to keep your communication, presentation, problem solving, consultative selling skills sharp.

texts.orig: Dr. Christopher Croner
texts.text: Dr. Christopher Croner

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Bio: Dr. Christopher Croner is a Principal with SalesDrive, LLC, a firm that specializes in the selection and deployment of high performing salespeople. Dr. Croner is co-author of the book, Never Hire a Bad Salesperson Again, detailing his research and practice in identifying the non- teachable personality traits common to top producers. Dr. Croner developed the proprietary DriveTest® diagnostics system, including the Drive Interview® for salesperson selection. Using this system, he has helped over 750 companies worldwide to hire and develop topperforming salespeople.
texts.text: Bio: Dr. Christopher Croner is a Principal with SalesDrive, LLC, a firm that specializes in the selection and deployment of high performing salespeople. texts.label: text
texts.orig: The DriveTest's key component is measuring the three non-teachable characteristics our research have found to be critical for high-performing 'hunter' salespeople: Need for Achievement, Competitiveness, and Optimism, collectively known as Drive.  We also measure the more teachable core skills important for just about every sales position, including Confidence, Persuasiveness, and Relationship skills.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5. What are the best results you've seen from your sales assessment/training process?
texts.text: 5. What are the best results you've seen from your sales assessment/training process?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The key benefit to expect from using the DriveTest is identifying higher-potential sales candidates to move to the interview process, rather than spending time with candidates who simply tell you what you want to hear.  The DriveTest was validated with salespeople in a variety of industries.  Our research found that those who were scoring a 4 or 5 on Drive (the highest levels), were almost twice as likely to be identified as a sales leader by their manager than those scoring a 1 or 2.

texts.text: 6. What are the most important skills you can have as a sales trainer?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: One of the most important skills for a sales trainer is targeting training to a salesperson's specific needs, rather than a 'one size fits all' approach.  After we have identified each person's unique training needs, listening is also critical to understand his or her personal vision and goals.  Finally, holding the salesperson accountable with regular follow-up is essential.
texts.text: One of the most important skills for a sales trainer is targeting training to a salesperson's specific needs, rather than a 'one size fits all' approach.  After we have identified each person's unique training needs, listening is also critical to understand his or her personal vision and goals. texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 7. Why should companies invest in sales assessment?
texts.text: 7. Why should companies invest in sales assessment?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Unfortunately, many sales managers end up feeling burned by candidates who talked a good game in the interview, but did not perform well thereafter, costing hundreds of thousands of dollars in missed targets, lost customers, and salary/benefits.  Beyond the age of 21-22, we cannot increase Drive, which is the easiest thing for a candidate to fake in the interview and the hardest thing to accurately rate.  Sales candidates can be especially skilled at figuring out what you want to hear . . . and that may be the only sale you get out of them.  Using a well-constructed, validated assessment saves time and allows you to focus on candidates who are much more likely to perform well for you.

texts.text: 8. What was your most important learning experience?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As discussed in our book, one of my most important learning experiences came when we were first developing our Drive model over a decade ago.  We had a candidate who scored strong on both Need for Achievement and Competitiveness who performed poorly attempting to sell a product new to his market with a long sales cycle.  As we learned, this type of product requires an evangelist with unwavering Optimism.  Unfortunately, this salesperson's was
texts.text: As discussed in our book, one of my most important learning experiences came when we were first developing our Drive model over a decade ago.  We had a candidate who scored strong on both Need for Achievement and Competitiveness who performed poorly attempting to sell a product new to his market with a long sales cycle.  As we learned, this type of product requires an evangelist with unwavering Optimism.  Unfortunately, this salesperson's was

texts.label: text
texts.orig: pessimistic, and he had trouble overcoming objections.  He parted ways with the company after 6 months, offering to pay back every dollar of salary he received. This caused us to research Optimism in depth, recognizing that without it, even a highly motivated salesperson can lack the certainty and perseverance necessary to succeed.

texts.orig: 10. What advice would you give a new sales trainer?
texts.text: 10. What advice would you give a new sales trainer?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Focus on developing skills that are teachable (e.g. persuasiveness, relationship skills, time management), rather than trying to instill traits that we cannot teach, such as Drive.  Use assessments up front to determine each salesperson's innate level of Drive and their scores on the teachable skills, make sure they are in a role that fits their level of Drive (i.e. Hunter vs. Farmer), and develop the teachable skills thereafter.

texts.text: Sales Training is about creating a lasting change to the thinking, approach, behavior, strategy, tactics, skills, process, methodology and

texts.orig: 6. What are the most important skills you can have as a sales trainer?
texts.text: 6. What are the most important skills you can have as a sales trainer?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: An ability and willingness to be oriented to others. Really, truly listening and remembering and empathizing with participants makes a big difference in your delivery. A lot of trainers get this backwards. They focus on their own delivery and worry about saying the right thing, looking smart, being right, etc. They get so caught up in the content or in their own presentation that they miss the needs of the individuals in the training group. This can be learned, but it takes a certain kind of humility and vulnerability to be this sort of sales trainer.

texts.text: 7. Why should companies invest in sales training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Trick question! Not all companies should invest in sales training. The companies who will benefit from sales training are the ones who:
texts.text: Trick question! Not all companies should invest in sales training. The companies who will benefit from sales training are the ones who:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: - want their sellers to develop new skills and understand that will require investing TIME and money for more than a workshop.
texts.text: want their sellers to develop new skills and understand that will require investing TIME and money for more than a workshop.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: - have sales managers who will also attend training so they can reinforce the skills and extend the learning.
texts.text: have sales managers who will also attend training so they can reinforce the skills and extend the learning.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: - recognize that there's a difference between product training and training for sales skills.
texts.text: recognize that there's a difference between product training and training for sales skills.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: - are more interested in long-term success than in making this month's numbers.
texts.text: are more interested in long-term success than in making this month's numbers.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: - have other sales productivity systems in place and don't think sales training is some kind of magic bullet.
texts.text: have other sales productivity systems in place and don't think sales training is some kind of magic bullet.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For companies that are capable of handling it, they should invest in quality training because it will improve top line revenue, retain and attract top sales talent, improve customer satisfaction and protect their brand. I can't imagine why any company would want untrained sellers haphazardly representing their brand and hurting their image.

texts.orig: 8. What was your most important learning experience?
texts.text: 8. What was your most important learning experience?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: I'm pretty hard-headed, so my most important learning experiences have usually involved some kind of failure. Being called out for being a horrible Sales Manager in my first job was humbling and made me really take stock of who I was and how I was coming across to others. Fortunately, I was able to abandon my stubbornness and try some new things. Being surrounded by really smart, caring people helped me see alternatives and gave me the positive feedback I needed to sustain that change.

texts.orig: Bio: Acumen Management Group, Ltd. president, is a sales leadership professional who 'operationalizes' sales management systems and processes to pull sales results out of the doldrums into the fresh zone of predictable revenue. As a sales management thought leader Ken is recognized as an expert in sales execution, channel management, revenue generation, sales analysis, compensation, forecasting, recruitment, and training within the sales function. It doesn't reflect the commercial or interpersonal situations which salespeople find themselves in on a daily basis. All of our Sales Training is based in the real world of B2B sales and we don't shirk the difficult topics or the tough conversations.

texts.orig: I always look at 2 key sets of metrics, to determine success:
texts.text: I always look at 2 key sets of metrics, to determine success:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1.  Hard metrics such as increase deal conversion rates and deal values. Improved competitive win rates, earlier decisions to qualify out of opportunities, reducing the cost of sale and opportunity costs.

texts.orig: 7. Why should companies invest in sales training?
texts.text: 7. Why should companies invest in sales training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The key word in this question is 'invest'. So often sales training is seen either as a necessary evil or as something to do because we have some sales enablement budget. The reality is the best sales training is an investment, not just in the growth of your team, but in the likelihood that they will continue to meet or exceed the targets which you have set for them.
texts.text: The key word in this question is 'invest'. So often sales training is seen either as a necessary evil or as something to do because we have some sales enablement budget. The reality is the best sales training is an investment, not just in the growth of your team, but in the likelihood that they will continue to meet or exceed the targets which you have set for them.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The world of B2B sales is rapidly evolving, as the balance of power shifts from vendors to customers. Those vendors who invest wisely in the right type of training and development for their sales teams, will ensure they remain relevant and value adding to the customers they serve.

texts.orig: 8. What was your most important learning experience?
texts.text: 8. What was your most important learning experience?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Learning the expression 'I don't know, but I'll find out for you'. As a young sales professional, I didn't want to display my ignorance, so instead I would try to come up with an answer to any and every question. Eventually I learned that no-one expects you to know everything, they are just as happy if you go away and find the right answer and then come back to them.

texts.orig: 10. What advice would you give a new sales trainer?
texts.text: 10. What advice would you give a new sales trainer?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Don't feel the need to know everything. There is usually a huge amount of knowledge, experience and war stories within any group you are training, so tap into that.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: I had my own company for close to 40 years selling advertising to small businesses. I retired almost 7 years ago and wrote a book called Selling Fearlessly, which has done very well. The book led to a website, www.sellingfearlessly.com, which led to people calling me from all over the world seeking help. I've done some professional coaching as well, although I didn't want to do it at first. texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 2. What do you incorporate in your sales training? Can you describe the process?
texts.text: 2. What do you incorporate in your sales training? Can you describe the process?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: It's so individual that it's hard to describe a general process. It really depends on who the person is and what he or she is seeking. For example, I was working with a client who was sending out Emails to get business and he was giving too much information in those Emails. So I advised him to use the telephone, as well as limit the amount of information he was giving. He needed to interest them instead of trying to give a presentation in an Email. His mind just opened up to this and he realized what he'd been doing was wrong. So he changed it and started to get business left and right. It really depends on the individual and what he or she needs.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 3. What is the key component in your sales training?
texts.text: 3. What is the key component in your sales training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In the book, I wrote about the sales triangle, which is also the key component of every sales training. I teach salespeople the 3 sides of the triangle, which they need to internalize, in order to be successful.
texts.text: In the book, I wrote about the sales triangle, which is also the key component of every sales training. I teach salespeople the 3 sides of the triangle, which they need to internalize, in order to be successful.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The first side of the sales triangle is mental attitude. As a salesperson, you have to have a strong mental attitude and can't approach people from a position of subservience. You need to believe in what you're doing and you have to know that you're bringing value to the people.
texts.text: The first side of the sales triangle is mental attitude. As a salesperson, you have to have a strong mental attitude and can't approach people from a position of subservience. You need to believe in what you're doing and you have to know that you're bringing value to the people.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The second side of the triangle is work habits. You just need to do the work and work hard. Give 8 to 12 presentations a week instead of just 4. You can't get away from not doing the work if you want to be successful.
texts.text: The second side of the triangle is work habits. You just need to do the work and work hard. Give 8 to 12 presentations a week instead of just 4. You can't get away from not doing the work if you want to be successful.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The third side of the triangle is knowledge/salesmanship. You have to know sales backwards, forwards and sideways. You must know your own business and every aspect of it. You also have to know your competition, so you can outsell them and bring more value than they can.
texts.text: The third side of the triangle is knowledge/salesmanship. You have to know sales backwards, forwards and sideways. You must know your own business and every aspect of it. You also have to know your competition, so you can outsell them and bring more value than they can.

texts.orig: 4. What are the best results you've seen from your sales training process?
texts.text: 4. What are the best results you've seen from your sales training process?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: One client I was working with was running into the same objection 8 times out of

Bring it up instead of waiting for the client to bring it up. Once he implemented this, he created an enormous sale from it and became much more successful. It's wonderful to get feedback like this.

texts.text: 5. What are the most important skills you can have as a sales trainer?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You also need to internalize the three sides of the triangle I mentioned earlier: have a strong mental attitude, work hard and be knowledgeable so you can bring value to your clients.
texts.text: You also need to internalize the three sides of the triangle I mentioned earlier: have a strong mental attitude, work hard and be knowledgeable so you can bring value to your clients.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Besides, you have to be able to approach people from a position of equality because this is what gets people to respect you and do business with you. You must demand that respect by being knowledgeable, by putting them first and by making it your mission to bring them value.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 6. Why should companies invest in sales training?
texts.text: 6. Why should companies invest in sales training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: I was working with a women who had been hired by a company that just sent her out there without any training. So she wasn't successful and got frustrated. It's obvious to me that you need to train your salespeople in order to be successful. If a company isn't smart enough to provide sales training, sales people should get training on their own. It's worth it for a company to pay for it because sales trainers can perform miracles. Sometimes companies are already very successful and don't think they need the training, but they don't realize how much more successful they could be if they invested in it.

It's obvious to me that you need to train your salespeople in order to be successful. If a company isn't smart enough to provide sales training, sales people should get training on their own. It's worth it for a company to pay for it because sales trainers can perform miracles. texts.text: 7. What was your most important learning experience?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The most important learning experience is the sales triangle I mentioned above, the 3 attributes you need to be successful. But also, you need to believe in the product you're selling because your job isn't to sell people, it's to bring value to them. If you bring them great value, the selling will come naturally.

But also, you need to believe in the product you're selling because your job isn't to sell people, it's to bring value to them. If you bring them great value, the selling will come naturally.

texts.orig: 8. What advice would you give to salespeople as a Trainer?
texts.text: 8. What advice would you give to salespeople as a Trainer?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Sell value and care about the customer instead of focusing on your numbers. Put the customer first, understand their problems and help them find the best solution to it. Also, be knowledgeable, educate yourself with all the content and books that are out there, so you can educate your customers. Never stop learning.

texts.orig: Frank Cespedes
texts.text: Frank Cespedes

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Bio: Frank Cespedes teaches at Harvard Business School. His book, Aligning Strategy and Sales: The Choices, Systems, and Behaviors that Drive Effective Selling (Harvard Business Review Press) has been called 'the best sales book of the year' (Strategy + Business), 'a must read' (Gartner Group), and 'perhaps the best sales book ever' (Forbes).
texts.text: Bio: Frank Cespedes teaches at Harvard Business School. His book, Aligning Strategy and Sales: The Choices, Systems, and Behaviors that Drive Effective Selling (Harvard Business Review Press) has been called 'the best sales book of the year' (Strategy + Business), 'a must read' (Gartner Group), and 'perhaps the best sales book ever' (Forbes).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 1.How did you get interested in the topic of sales?
texts.text: 1.How did you get interested in the topic of sales?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: My academic research always focused on go-to-market elements of business, including channels and sales management. Then, when I left academia and ran a business for 12 years, I had to meet payroll and sell. Then, after getting lucky in business and returning to academia, I taught Strategy and found there is remarkably little research about how to link strategy with field execution and especially with sales efforts. Yet, U.S. companies alone spend about $900 billion annually on sales efforts. That's 3x what they spend on ALL ad media, more than 10x what they spend on all digital media, and more than 20x what they spend on social media. Selling is, by far, the most expensive part of strategy execution for most companies.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 2. As you see it, why should
texts.text: 2. As you see it, why should

texts.label: text
texts.orig: companies invest in sales training?
texts.text: companies invest in sales training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Someone once told me that many companies maintain their equipment better than their people. If so, they ultimately get what they don't maintain. This is especially risky and short-sighted in sales. Research indicates that, across industries, turnover in sales averages about 25-30% annually. This means that, at many firms, the equivalent of the entire sales force must be replaced and trained every four years or so. Any talk about 'talent management' which ignores a talent requirement of that magnitude is just talk.
texts.text: Someone once told me that many companies maintain their equipment better than their people. If so, they ultimately get what they don't maintain. This is especially risky and short-sighted in sales. Research indicates that, across industries, turnover in sales averages about 25-30% annually. This means that, at many firms, the equivalent of the entire sales force must be replaced and trained every four years or so. Any talk about 'talent management' which ignores a talent requirement of that magnitude is just talk.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Despite what you often read in many blogs these days, selling is not a science reducible to a few timeless rules. Many variables affect market performance and selling effectiveness besides the sales person. But as the phrase implies, 'sales reps' represent the organization and its capabilities to the market. They need reinforcement, periodic upgrading and adaptation of skills to new market circumstances, and the positive motivation that is a by-product of any good developmental process. Stated more bluntly, you must invest in training salespeople (and other professionals who deal with a range of changing situations) because of what the U.S. Air Force calls the '8 P's' in its training of pilots: 'Proper Prior Planning and Preparation Prevents Piss-Poor Performance.'

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 3. What are the key components of effective sales training?
texts.text: 3. What are the key components of effective sales training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Build Your Team, Not another Firm's Team. There is no such thing as effective selling if it's not linked to your firm's strategy and business objectives. So first focus on identifying the selling behaviors required by that strategy and the target customers inherent in those strategic choices.
texts.text: Build Your Team, Not another Firm's Team. There is no such thing as effective selling if it's not linked to your firm's strategy and business objectives. So first focus on identifying the selling behaviors required by that strategy and the target customers inherent in those strategic choices.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Develop the Fundamentals. Train and develop salespeople in a consistent and measurable way with attention to actual behaviors (not only attitudes) that can be practiced and taught, not just preached.
texts.text: Develop the Fundamentals. Train and develop salespeople in a consistent and measurable way with attention to actual behaviors (not only attitudes) that can be practiced and taught, not just preached.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Do Experiential Learning. Selling is a performance art. Acquiring behavioral skills (versus concepts) requires repetition.  People must try a new behavior multiple times before it becomes comfortable and effective. This means that on-the-job learning is crucial. But in many organizations, 'on-the-job' training is a euphemism for no real training at all. It's a random process dependent on a particular sales manager's calendar, temperament, and ability. That's a mistake.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Given the amount of money spent on sales by companies (an average of 10% of revenue across industries, and often more in B2B companies), senior executives have a responsibility to manage and measure that investment more rigorously.
texts.text: Given the amount of money spent on sales by companies (an average of 10% of revenue across industries, and often more in B2B companies), senior executives have a responsibility to manage and measure that investment more rigorously.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Follow-Up. The greatest impact from training, according to many studies, is what happens after training sessions: follow-up aimed at ensuring that people apply the relevant behaviors. Too often, however, nothing happens after training initiatives. Effective sales training must be linked to subsequent performance reviews, ride-alongs, win-loss analyses, and other core performance management practices.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 4. How is technology shaping sales processes and training requirements and goals?
texts.text: 4. How is technology shaping sales processes and training requirements and goals?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: First, let's be clear about what technology is NOT doing: it's not disintermediating, or replacing, sales people with ecommerce. According to U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, the number of people in sales occupations in 2015 was the same as in 1992-before the commercialization of the internet. And this almost certainly understates the real numbers: in an increasingly service economy, business developers in more firms are called Associates, Partners, Managing Directors, or Vice Presidents, not listed in a 'sales' category for reporting purposes.
texts.text: First, let's be clear about what technology is NOT doing: it's not disintermediating, or replacing, sales people with ecommerce. According to U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, the number of people in sales occupations in 2015 was the same as in 1992-before the commercialization of the internet. And this almost certainly understates the real numbers: in an increasingly service economy, business developers in more firms are called Associates, Partners, Managing Directors, or Vice Presidents, not listed in a 'sales' category for reporting purposes.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: But technology is realigning sales tasks as buyers conduct online research about products and prices before meeting with a salesperson. As a result, there is more pressure for salespeople to add value during the customer encounter and, due to online technologies, customers can more easily interact with other customers and with others at the selling company besides the sales person. Sales training must focus more precisely on key tasks so that reps are more than walking-andtalking direct-mail vehicles and, in many companies, sales training needs more emphasis on how other functions in the firm affect, and are affected by, selling behaviors.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 5. What advice would you give to a new sales trainer?
texts.text: 5. What advice would you give to a new sales trainer?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Focus on Buying Behavior. Selling is always more about the buyer than the seller. What's important in sales training should be determined by up-to-date knowledge about who buys, why, and how. Training should reflect how buying, and therefore required sales tasks, work today and tomorrow, not yesterday.
texts.text: Focus on Buying Behavior. Selling is always more about the buyer than the seller. What's important in sales training should be determined by up-to-date knowledge about who buys, why, and how. Training should reflect how buying, and therefore required sales tasks, work today and tomorrow, not yesterday.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Beware of One-Size-Fits-All Methodologies. Selling is the most contextually determined set of skills in a firm: what works at that company does not necessarily work here, because sales effectiveness is a function of a company's strategy, target customers, and the relevant sales tasks for those buyers. Sometimes an off-the-shelf training tool can address the desired outcome. But more often, customization is required.

Selling is the most contextually determined set of skills in a firm: what works at that company does not necessarily work here, because sales effectiveness is a function of a company's strategy, target customers, and the relevant sales tasks for those buyers. Sometimes an off-the-shelf training tool can address the desired outcome. But more often, customization is required.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Get Out There, Regularly. It's not the market's responsibility to be nice to your company's strategy and sales process. It's your responsibility to understand the changing market and adapt. You must stay in on-going touch with actual customers. As Sam Walton repeatedly told his leadership team, 'There ain't many customers at headquarters.'

texts.orig: 2. What do you incorporate in your sales training? Can you describe the process?
texts.text: 2. What do you incorporate in your sales training? Can you describe the process?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: All sales positions I have held have always included sales training developed and presented by that entity. Typically speaking classroom style lecturing and a small
texts.text: All sales positions I have held have always included sales training developed and presented by that entity. Typically speaking classroom style lecturing and a small

texts.label: text
texts.orig: amount of group activities. However, as a sales trainer myself for my company, I believe a more hands on approach is more desired. I will have the new employee job shadow me for 2 days in the field showing them 'how' the job is truly done. Then, I will spend 2 days in their area watching how they interact and speak and critique as needed. After my training with my new employees I stay closely connected to them reaching out periodically, asking how things are going, telling them tips and tricks I have picked up in the field and so forth.

texts.text: 3. How does technology shape your sales process? What tools do you use?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Technology has made MY approach in my sales process key. I typically rely solely on my mobile device. I use it mostly by making phone calls, texting, and sometimes have certain apps I lean on for support if I am uncertain of an answer. I also do carry a laptop with me at all times, but find I typically do not use it as I am unable to connect to wifi.

texts.orig: 7. Why should companies invest in sales training?
texts.text: 7. Why should companies invest in sales training?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Any company can have a sellable product, but at the end of the day it is who is selling the product that typically decides whether or not the prospect becomes a customer. If companies see value and make the investment into properly and effectively training their sales team, everyone wins.

texts.orig: 8. What was your most important learning experience?
texts.text: 8. What was your most important learning experience?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This is a difficult question to answer, my most important learning experience probably has been realizing that I have to rely on myself and no one else. I can have all the training manuals at my fingertips but if I do not push myself no one can.

texts.orig: 9. How do you connect with your team?
texts.text: 9. How do you connect with your team?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When meeting with my team I will make it interactive, making everyone feel and become part of my team. I tend to talk through challenges with my team to create solutions together instead of deciding to run with my sole idea on my own.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 10. What advice would you give a new sales trainer?
texts.text: 10. What advice would you give a new sales trainer?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The biggest advice I would recommend is knowing that, you the trainer, know more than your students. Preparation is key, however, you will probably forget something along the way and instead of noting the mistake continue with your presentation and include the missing information at a different time. The students do not know how you plan to present or in what order.
